paragraphs.name: 7c68
paragraphs.text: However, are you able to answer this quick question? What is the output of the following function?

8800aca12a6.title: The best manager I ever had was non-technical.

paragraphs.text: The best manager I ever had was non-technical. It kept him out of the weeds and meant he had to have confidence I his staff. I have had good and bad managers of both the technical and non-technical variety. It really depends on a lot of factors (size, skill, and experience of your team to name a few) as to weather or not you need a manager who can code.

Nice article and so true. I manage developers, write and review code. For fun I have just written a batched asynchronous recursive function that can feed it’s self. Did this on my commute so I could get the list of all packages that would be installed from a list of npm packages. Not the best or right way of doing this but it was fun.

88eadd885884.title: Very good points, though I would add that the real trick is remaining technical without losing…

paragraphs.text: Very good points, though I would add that the real trick is remaining technical without losing sight of the bigger picture. You are the leader for a reason - so don’t forget to lead, and that covers a lot more than just technical prowess. If you screw up, it could literally mean the end of the team, product, and/or company.
paragraphs.name: eed8

249f9d2258c7.title: I am a Development Team Lead who manages A small team of only 5 developers and QA.

paragraphs.text: I am a Development Team Lead who manages A small team of only 5 developers and QA. I have a QA background and still spend about 20% of my time working QA tasks and automation.
